chat.text: ‚ö†Ô∏è Twitter is now marking Substack links as unsafe - The Verge - https://www.theverge.com/2023/4/7/23674936/twitter-marking-substack-links-unsafe

Twitter is now marking Substack links as unsafe - The Verge

Twitter has started marking links to Substack as potentially spammy or unsafe as it sees the new Substack Notes feature as a hostile rival. Last Thursday, Twitter blocked people who use Substack from embedding tweets into their stories, and it began blocking engagement on tweets containing links since Friday morning. Although its founders have recently spoken out about how Twitter is treating their platform, Twitter hasn't disclosed what justification it's using for the warning. Meanwhile, CEO Elon Musk hasn‚Äôt tweeted anything about Substack recently, and when reached for comment, Twitter‚Äôs press email auto-replied with a poop emoji.

- Twitter is marking links to Substack as potentially spammy or unsafe
- Twitter sees the new Substack Notes feature as a hostile rival
- Twitter blocked people who use Substack from embedding tweets into their stories
- Twitter began blocking engagement on tweets containing links since Friday morning
- Twitter hasn't disclosed what justification it's using for the warning
- CEO Elon Musk hasn‚Äôt tweeted anything about Substack recently
- Twitter‚Äôs press email auto-replied with a poop emoji

Introducing Substack Notes

Substack has announced a new feature called Notes, which will allow writers to post short-form content and share ideas on a subscription-based network without ads. The network has already grown to 35 million active subscriptions to writers, with more than 2 million being paid subscriptions.¬†

- Substack is launching a new feature called Notes for writers to share short-form content and ideas
- Unlike social media, the subscription-based network runs without ads
- Substack already boasts 35 million active subscriptions to writers, with over 2 million being paid subscriptions
- The goal is to foster conversations between writers and among readers
- The focus is on building a system that lets people control the contours and boundaries of their subscription universe, making it easy to keep trolls out and valuable participants in
- The platform aims to construct a constructive discussion environment that seeks understanding and holds onto tension for great art and new ideas
- Substack says that it enters uncharted territory with the subscription network, and there is much potential to discover.

‚ö†Ô∏è AWS Announces Open Source Mountpoint for Amazon S3 - https://www.infoq.com/news/2023/03/mountpoint-amazon-s3/

AWS Announces Open Source Mountpoint for Amazon S3

Amazon Web Services (AWS) has announced Mountpoint for Amazon S3, an open-source file client for parallel, high-throughput access to Amazon S3 for data lake applications. The client translates API calls to S3 object API calls, supports random and sequential read operations and listing of files and directories. It is built on the Common Runtime used by most AWS SDKs, but does not support writes. AWS researchers warned that treating S3 as a file system could lead to incorrect assumptions about its API Mountpoint for Amazon S3 is a new open-source file client to access high throughput on Amazon S3 The alpha version provides a local-mount point with high single-instance transfer rates It is designed for large-scale analytics applications that read large amounts of S3 data in parallel It supports random and sequential read operations and file and directory listing It is not designed for writes (PUTs) and only supports sequential writes in the future Mountpoint is intended to map S3 buckets (prefixes) into local file systems and achieve high throughput access to objects The client does not emulate operations like directory renames or support POSIX filesystem features Released under the Apache License 2.0, it is still in alpha and not yet ready for production workloads.

‚ö†Ô∏è Flipper Zero banned by Amazon for being a ‚Äòcard skimming device‚Äô - https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/technology/flipper-zero-banned-by-amazon-for-being-a-card-skimming-device-/

Flipper Zero banned by Amazon for being a ‚Äòcard skimming device‚Äô

Amazon has banned the Flipper Zero portable multi-tool for pen-testers, labeling it a card-skimming device. Flipper Devices' CEO Pavel Zhovner has asked Amazon to reconsider the ban, stating that the device is not capable of skimming bank cards. The Flipper Zero is a portable pen-testing tool that can experiment and debug various digital and hardware devices across multiple protocols. Users¬†have demonstrated the device's abilities, from cloning digital¬†keys to unlocking cars and opening garage doors. The device can still be bought on the maker's official website, which¬†is regularly restocked. However,¬†the Brazilian National Telecommunications Agency has seized incoming Flipper Zero purchases based on alleged use by criminals.¬†
- Amazon has banned the sale of Flipper Zero
- CEO Pavel Zhovner asked Amazon to reconsider the¬†ban
- Flipper Zero is a portable pen-testing tool that helps debug various digital and hardware devices
- It can clone digital keys, unlock cars and open garage doors
- Device now only available on maker's official website;¬†Brazilian National Telecommunications Agency seized incoming purchases
- Failure to remove all restricted product listings may lead to account deactivation
- Amazon's policy prohibits sale or listing of card skimming devices, key duplicating devices and shoplifting devices¬†
- It is unknown as to whether the ban will be¬†temporary or maintained
